awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: The Impact of Product Market Competition on the Labor Market
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund a doctoral dissertation that uses unique data to measure the effects of high market concentration on workers, including work to better understand the links between the competition a firm faces for the products it sells and the competition it faces for workers it seeks to employ. Economic theory predicts that workers will earn higher wages when there are many employers offering jobs. However, in some local areas there are only a few employers. In this kind of concentrated labor market, employers have an advantage because workers lack viable alternative offers. Furthermore, if a firm has a dominant position in the market for the product/s it sells, it may also be dominant in the labor market. This kind of firm would then have an outsized role on both its workers and its consumers. The project will systematically investigate how concentration affects wages, employment spell duration, and profit pass-through. The results of this project may help policymakers understand the costs and benefits of policies designed to reduce market concentration. 

This project is based on three administrative datasets spanning the years 2008 to 2020. The first is the quasi-universe of employment spells year-by-year; the research team will use this to systematically construct the employment and wage bill concentration indexes. This first dataset lacks the ability to track workers over time for confidentiality reasons. The second dataset is an employer-employee panel with information on wages, duration of spell, industry, occupation and some demographic information. This dataset allows us to follow workers and firms over the years. Finally, the third dataset contains balance sheet information at the firm’s level (sales, profits, inventories, etc.). What makes these datasets unique is the possibility to merge them using a unique firm identifier.  The project builds the concentration index by labor market and merges that measure with our panel data and each firm’s balance sheet. The result is a new panel in which we can look at how wages vary depending on concentrations in the product and labor market. This analysis represents the core of the project. The first step will be to properly define labor markets. We will rely on traditional notions like occupation by commuting zone, in addition to a clustering approach based workers’ transitions across firms (applying newly developed techniques in stochastic block modeling). We will then run labor regressions to document patterns between wages (level and growth), concentration and profits and sales. We want to document whether workers in more concentrated markets are better or worse off. As pointed out above, in more concentrated markets, firms are likely to have more bargaining power, yet they should also be more productive firms, and therefore be paying higher wages. These regressions will not inform us on the causality of market concentration on wages though. To alleviate that point, the next step of the project will be to propose a search-and-matching model in which a discrete number of firms compete for workers and use our empirical results to calibrate it. We will then be able to run counterfactual analyses on the impact of concentration on workers’ welfare.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes and Findings

This research explored how concentration of firms in local labor markets affects workers' wages and job finding rates. In labor markets where a few firms dominate the market, workers may face limited job options, which gives employers an advantage in setting wages (a channel that has been studied in other academic papers). At the same time, firms operating in concentrated labor markets are likely to be different from firms in non-concentrated labor markets (they might, for instance, operate in different industries or geographic locations), and these differences could lead to higher wages. How wages vary with labor market concentration is not straightforward.

This project uses two French employer-employee match datasets spanning the years 2008 to 2021 to look at this question. The first one is a repeated cross-section of the universe of French jobs. It allows us to construct fine measures of local labor market concentration, and of other aggregate statistics, including the mean wage paid to workers or the transition to and from unemployment in a given local market. The second is a panel data, that covers around 10% of the French jobs, and allows us to follow workers across years, and perform regressions with worker’s fixed effects or event-studies.

We find that concentration and wages are positively correlated in all our empirical exercises. Workers receive higher wages in more concentrated labor markets. The results are both economically and statistically significant: in our preferred specification, more concentrated labor markets pay on average 7% more than less concentrated markets. How can we reconcile these findings with the increase in firms’ monopsony power? We postulate that firms operating in concentrated markets are more productive, and that the increase in productivity dominates the increase in market power – leading to higher output produced by the firm, and higher wages received by its workers, despite an increasing in firm’s markdown on wages. This can be rationalized by increasing entry costs in some markets, making them more concentrated in equilibrium as fewer firms operate.

We propose a general equilibrium model of the labor market with an entry decision by firms, and estimate this model on the data described above. We then analyze the effect of restricting entry of unproductive firms on wages and output. Our results suggest that having fewer but more productive firms in a market actually improves wages and overall economic outcomes, despite increasing unemployment and labor market concentration. These results can inform public policy decisions, especially in debates about whether policies should aim to reduce or encourage labor market concentration.

Other Products and Publications

In addition to the findings described above, the research produced and released several datasets on labor market concentration and wages in France, available on the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR). These datasets contain concentration measures and labor market statistics of local labor markets for the universe of the French economy.

The project’s findings have already been shared in a PhD dissertation, a working paper and several academic presentations, and has lead to a new research agenda for co-PI Guillaume Nevo, on the effects of firm’s entry on labor market outcomes. More papers are expected to follow. These publications will provide further insights into the efficiency of firm’s entry decision on total output.

Broader Impacts on Society

This project challenges traditional views about labor market concentration, highlighting a new mechanism through which higher market concentration may actually benefit both workers and firms. While it is often assumed that dominant firms exploit their power and suppress wages, the study found that more productive firms, even when they dominate a market, tend to offer better wages and create a more efficient economy overall as the increase in productivity dominates the increase in firm’s monopsony power. This insight could help policymakers make informed decisions about regulations that aim to tackle firm competition and how these regulations improve or not labor market efficiency.

More specifically, this research shows that restricting the entry of less productive firms into the market can improve overall economic output and wages despite increasing concentration. Policymakers may consider this approach when designing industrial strategies or labor market regulations – preventing the entry of unproductive firms could reduce inefficiencies by reducing congestion in the labor market, leading to higher output and wages.
